questions.question: Which anion gives effervescence with dilute HCl, producing a gas that turns limewater milky?
questions.explanation: CO₃²⁻ + 2H⁺ → CO₂(g) + H₂O. CO₂ turns limewater milky: Ca(OH)₂ + CO₂ → CaCO₃↓ + H₂O. (Syllabus 6b & 6c)

questions.question: Which anion gives a white precipitate with acidified BaCl₂ that is insoluble in dilute HCl?
questions.explanation: SO₄²⁻ + Ba²⁺ → BaSO₄(s) white precipitate, insoluble in acids. (Syllabus 6b)

questions.question: Which anion gives a white precipitate with AgNO₃ that dissolves completely in dilute NH₃?
questions.explanation: Cl⁻ + Ag⁺ → AgCl(s) white precipitate. AgCl dissolves in dilute NH₃ forming soluble [Ag(NH₃)₂]⁺ complex. (Syllabus 6b)

questions.question: Which anion gives a yellow precipitate with AgNO₃ that remains after adding dilute NH₃?
questions.explanation: I⁻ + Ag⁺ → AgI(s) yellow precipitate, insoluble in dilute NH₃. (Syllabus 6b)

questions.question: Which anion, when warmed with aluminium foil and aqueous NaOH, produces a gas that turns damp red litmus paper blue?
questions.explanation: NO₃⁻ is reduced by Al in NaOH: NO₃⁻ → NH₃(g). NH₃ turns damp red litmus blue. (Syllabus 6b & 6c)

questions.question: A solution gives a white precipitate with AgNO₃. The precipitate dissolves completely when dilute NH₃ is added. Which anion is present?
questions.explanation: Only Cl⁻ gives a white AgCl precipitate soluble in dilute NH₃. AgI (yellow) is insoluble. (Syllabus 6b)

questions.question: Which anion produces a gas with dilute HCl that turns limewater milky but does NOT decolorize acidified KMnO₄?
questions.explanation: CO₃²⁻ produces CO₂ (turns limewater milky) but CO₂ does NOT decolorize KMnO₄. SO₃²⁻ produces SO₂ which DOES decolorize KMnO₄. (Syllabus 6b & 6c)

questions.question: A solution gives a yellow precipitate with AgNO₃. The precipitate remains unchanged after adding dilute NH₃. Which anion is present?
questions.explanation: Only I⁻ gives a yellow AgI precipitate insoluble in dilute NH₃. Cl⁻ gives white ppt that dissolves. (Syllabus 6b)
